Ru_trainchinese:
jiǎo: (сущ) нога, стопа

chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: The foot seems the most withdrawn from the perspective of a person because they are furthest part of the body from the head.
humanum_full_description_en:
From the sound of " flesh " and " but ", the original meaning is shin, that is, calf. The lower part of human and animal legs that touch the ground, support the body, and walk are called feet. "Shuowen": "The shin is also from the flesh, but the sound." Duan Yucai's note: "The shin is also. The "Dongfang Shuo Zhuan" says: "Kneeling and sitting." The thighs and feet are centered. The words of the feet are also true. Everyone who steps away must first shin. From the flesh, but the sound." "Mozi·Mingguixia": "When a sheep rises, touch it, and fold its feet." Du Fu's poem "Beizheng": "See Yeah crying on the back, greasy feet without socks."

" Foot " is also used for footsteps, running, etc. For example, in Su Shi's poem "Hu Paoquan": "The tiger moves the spring's eyes while walking, and the dragon makes waves for caressing his palms." Another example is the Yu Que poem "Gift Liu Yuyu" in the Yuan Dynasty: "Last year, I lied on Heng Yue and talked about the world.

The support of an implement, the lower end or tail of an article, is also called " feet ". For example, "The Book of the Southern Qi-The Five Elements": "The ancient building in the west of Bazhou City has cypress pillars for hundreds of years, and flowers have suddenly grown." Du Fu's "The Thatched House is Broken by the Autumn Wind": "The bedside house leaks and the rainy feet remain unbroken. "Song Dynasty Zhang Lei's poem "Su Fanxi": "The flat boat comes across the river, and the foot of the mountain is tied to my cable."

The " feet " is also used as the micro-root of the plant, as in Jia Sixie's "Qi Min Yao Shu-Huang Yi Huang Steam and Song" in the Northern Wei Dynasty: "The feet are born with cloth wheat on the mat, two inches thick."
humanum_short_description_en: From the sound of " flesh " and " but ", the original meaning is calf.
humanum_full_description:
從「肉」，「卻」聲，本義為脛，即小腿。人與動物腿的下端，接觸地面、支持身體和行走的部分，就稱為腳。《說文》：「脛也。从肉，卻聲。」段玉裁注：「脛也。《東方朔傳》曰：『結股腳。』謂跪坐之狀，股與腳以厀爲中。腳之言卻也。凡卻步必先脛。从肉，卻聲。」《墨子‧明鬼下》：「羊起而觸之，折其腳。」杜甫詩〈北征〉：「見耶背面啼，垢膩腳不襪。」

　　「腳」也用作腳步、奔走等。如蘇軾詩〈虎跑泉〉：「虎移泉眼趁行腳，龍作浪花供撫掌。」又如元代余闕詩〈贈劉禹玉〉：「去年臥衡岳，聊憩四海腳。」

　　器具的支撐、物品的下端或尾部，也稱為「腳」。如《南齊書‧五行志》：「巴州城西古樓腳柏柱數百年，忽生花。」杜甫〈茅屋為秋風所破歌〉：「床頭屋漏無乾處，雨腳如麻未斷絕。」宋代張耒詩〈宿樊溪〉：「扁舟橫江來，山腳繫吾纜。」

　　「腳」還用作植物的微根，如北魏賈思勰《齊民要術‧黃衣黃蒸及櫱》：「腳生，布麥於席上，厚二寸許。」

①人和某些動物身體最下部接觸地面的部分：腳心。腳掌。腳背。腳跟。腳步。腳印。腳法(指踢球、踢毽等的技巧)。腳鐐。腳踏實地(形容做事實事求是，不浮誇)。
②最下部：腳註。山腳。牆腳。
③剩下的廢料，渣滓：下腳料。
④(腳本)表演戲劇或拍攝影視所依據的底本。
⑤舊時指與體力搬運有關的：腳伕。腳行(háng)。腳錢。拉腳。
腳步 [ jiǎo bù ]: footstep; step
腳下 [ jiǎo xià ]: under the foot
腳踏實地 [ jiǎo tà shí dì ]: to have one's feet firmly planted on the ground (idiom); realistic without flights of fancy; steady and serious character
腳跟 [ jiǎo gēn ]: heel
①傳統戲曲中的人物類型。［例］崛，特立也。——《埤蒼》。［例］神明崛其特起。——張衡《西京賦》。［例］洪臺崛其獨出兮。——《文選·揚雄·甘泉賦》。［合］腳兒(也作“角兒”、“腳色”)；腳色(出身履歷；演員；人物)。
②另見jiǎo。

Chinese: Your foot is what allows you to withdraw or advance your body when playing sports.  
Meaning: foot
Hanzi: 脚
Story: The foot seems the most withdrawn from the perspective of a person because they are furthest part of the body from the head.
Kind: traditional

從「 肉 」，「 卻 」聲，本義為脛，即小腿。人與動物腿的下端，接觸地面、支持身體和行走的部分，就稱為腳。《說文》：「脛也。从肉，卻聲。」段玉裁注：「脛也。《東方朔傳》曰：『結股腳。』謂跪坐之狀，股與腳以厀爲中。腳之言卻也。凡卻步必先脛。从肉，卻聲。」《墨子‧明鬼下》：「羊起而觸之，折其腳。」杜甫詩〈北征〉：「見耶背面啼，垢膩腳不襪。」 「 腳 」也用作腳步、奔走等。如蘇軾詩〈虎跑泉〉：「虎移泉眼趁行腳，龍作浪花供撫掌。」又如元代余闕詩〈贈劉禹玉〉：「去年臥衡岳，聊憩四海腳。」 器具的支撐、物品的下端或尾部，也稱為「 腳 」。如《南齊書‧五行志》：「巴州城西古樓腳柏柱數百年，忽生花。」杜甫〈茅屋為秋風所破歌〉：「床頭屋漏無乾處，雨腳如麻未斷絕。」宋代張耒詩〈宿樊溪〉：「扁舟橫江來，山腳繫吾纜。」 「 腳 」還用作植物的微根，如北魏賈思勰《齊民要術‧黃衣黃蒸及櫱》：「腳生，布麥於席上，厚二寸許。」
From the sound of " flesh" and " but", the original meaning is shin, that is, calf. The lower part of human and animal legs that touch the ground, support the body, and walk are called feet. "Shuowen": "The shin is also from the flesh, but the sound." Duan Yucai's note: "The shin is also. The "Dongfang Shuo Zhuan" says: "Kneeling and sitting." The thighs and feet are centered. The words of the feet are also true. Everyone who steps away must first shin. From the flesh, but the sound." "Mozi·Mingguixia": "When a sheep rises, touch it, and fold its feet." Du Fu's poem "Beizheng": "See Yeah crying on the back, greasy feet without socks." " Foot" is also used for footsteps, running, etc. For example, in Su Shi's poem "Hu Paoquan": "The tiger moves the spring's eyes while walking, and the dragon makes waves for caressing his palms." Another example is the Yu Que poem "Gift Liu Yuyu" in the Yuan Dynasty: "Last year, I lied on Heng Yue and talked about the world. The support of an implement, the lower end or tail of an article, is also called " feet". For example, "The Book of the Southern Qi-The Five Elements": "The ancient building in the west of Bazhou City has cypress pillars for hundreds of years, and flowers have suddenly grown." Du Fu's "The Thatched House is Broken by the Autumn Wind": "The bedside house leaks and the rainy feet remain unbroken. "Song Dynasty Zhang Lei's poem "Su Fanxi": "The flat boat comes across the river, and the foot of the mountain is tied to my cable." The " feet" is also used as the micro-root of the plant, as in Jia Sixie's "Qi Min Yao Shu-Huang Yi Huang Steam and Song" in the Northern Wei Dynasty: "The feet are born with cloth wheat on the mat, two inches thick."

jiǎo
均同“脚”。

腳字的汉语字典释义

[①]［jiǎo］
同“脚1”。
[②]［jué］
同“脚2”。

腳字的康熙字典解释

【未集下】【肉字部】　腳； 康熙笔画：15； 页码：页989第20
【唐韻】居勺切【集韻】【韻會】訖約切，?音蹻。【說文】脛也。或作脚。【釋名】却也。以其坐時卻在後也。【荀子·正論篇】詈侮捽搏，捶笞臏腳。　又以足蹂物曰腳。【司馬相如·子虛賦】射麋腳麟。【註】郭璞曰：腳掎足。【文選·李善註】腳，謂持其麟也。

腳字的源字形

字源演变：

小篆楷体

字形对比：

中国大陆宋体台湾细明体香港明体韩国明朝体旧字形
腳字的起名意思

暂无。
